message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Manufacturing Consent
Paper Abstract: Chapter 6 empirically tests whether and how participatory technologies influence political attitudes. Using two original survey experiments and qualitative data from interviews and focus groups, this chapter examines the impact of awareness of the Direct Line on approval of President Putin and perceptions of voice. The results indicate that participatory technologies have a positive impact on attitudes toward authorities. It also argues that, while government responsiveness to citizen demands does improve attitudes toward autocrats, the mere presence of participation opportunities bolsters support regardless of authorities' response to these demands.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

1#!/usr/bin/env python3
     2"""
     3Validation script for triples_output.json
     4
     5Checks:
     61. Valid JSON format
     72. Required fields present
     83. Enum values correct (paper_type, entity_type, relation)
     94. Wikipedia URL format valid
    105. Wikipedia pages actually exist (HTTP HEAD request)
    116. Triples structure correct
    12"""
    13
    14import json
    15import sys
    16from pathlib import Path
    17from urllib.parse import urlparse
    18import urllib.request as urlreq
    19from urllib.error import HTTPError, URLError
    20
    21# Color codes for terminal output
    22RED = "\033[91m"
    23GREEN = "\033[92m"
    24YELLOW = "\033[93m"
    25BLUE = "\033[94m"
    26CYAN = "\033[96m"
    27END = "\033[0m"
    28
    29# Valid enum values
    30VALID_PAPER_TYPES = ["contribution", "survey"]
    31VALID_ENTITY_TYPES = ["task", "method", "data", "artifact", "tool", "concept", "other"]
    32VALID_RELATIONS = ["uses", "proposes"]
    33
    34# Cache for Wikipedia URL verification
    35_url_cache = {}
    36
    37
    38def verify_wikipedia_url(url: str) -> tuple[bool, str]:
    39    """
    40    Verify a Wikipedia URL exists using Wikipedia REST API.
    41
    42    Returns:
    43        (is_valid, error_message)
    44    """
    45    # Check cache first
    46    if url in _url_cache:
    47        return _url_cache[url]
    48
    49    # Extract page title from URL
    50    # URL format: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Page_Title
    51    if not url.startswith("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/"):
    52        msg = "Invalid Wikipedia URL format"
    53        _url_cache[url] = (False, msg)
    54        return False, msg
    55
    56    # Get page title from URL (everything after /wiki/)
    57    page_title = url.replace("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/", "")
    58
    59    # Use Wikipedia REST API to check if page exists
    60    # API endpoint: https://en.wikipedia.org/w/rest.php/v1/page/{title}
    61    api_url = f"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/rest.php/v1/page/{page_title}"
    62
    63    try:
    64        req = urlreq.Request(api_url, headers={'User-Agent': 'Mozilla/5.0 (validate_triple_json validator)'})
    65        with urlreq.urlopen(req, timeout=5) as response:
    66            if response.status == 200:
    67                _url_cache[url] = (True, "")
    68                return True, ""
    69            else:
    70                msg = f"Wikipedia API returned status {response.status}"
    71                _url_cache[url] = (False, msg)
    72                return False, msg
    73    except HTTPError as e:
    74        msg = f"HTTP {e.code}: Page not found or does not exist on Wikipedia"
    75        _url_cache[url] = (False, msg)
    76        return False, msg
    77    except URLError as e:
    78        msg = f"Network error: {e.reason}"
    79        _url_cache[url] = (False, msg)
    80        return False, msg
    81    except Exception as e:
    82        msg = f"Verification failed: {str(e)}"
    83        _url_cache[url] = (False, msg)
    84        return False, msg
    85
    86
    87def validate_analysis(file_path: Path, verify_urls: bool = True) -> tuple[bool, list[str]]:
    88    """
    89    Validate the analysis output file.
    90
    91    Args:
    92        file_path: Path to triples_output.json
    93        verify_urls: Whether to verify Wikipedia URLs exist (HTTP requests)
    94
    95    Returns:
    96        (is_valid, list_of_errors)
    97    """
    98    errors = []
    99
   100    # Check file exists
   101    if not file_path.exists():
   102        return False, [f"File not found: {file_path}"]
   103
   104    # Load JSON
   105    try:
   106        with open(file_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:
   107            data = json.load(f)
   108    except json.JSONDecodeError as e:
   109        return False, [f"Invalid JSON syntax: {e}\n   Fix: Ensure valid JSON formatting"]
   110
   111    # Check required top-level fields
   112    required_fields = ["paper_type", "triples"]
   113    for field in required_fields:
   114        if field not in data:
   115            errors.append(f"Missing required field: '{field}'\n   Fix: Add '{field}' to top-level JSON")
   116
   117    # Validate paper_type enum
   118    if "paper_type" in data:
   119        if data["paper_type"] not in VALID_PAPER_TYPES:
   120            errors.append(f"Invalid paper_type: '{data['paper_type']}'\n   Fix: Must be one of: {VALID_PAPER_TYPES}")
   121
   122    # Validate triples structure
   123    if "triples" in data:
   124        if not isinstance(data["triples"], list):
   125            errors.append("'triples' must be a list\n   Fix: Use array syntax: \"triples\": [...]")
   126        else:
   127            for idx, block in enumerate(data["triples"]):
   128                # Check it's a dict
   129                if not isinstance(block, dict):
   130                    errors.append(f"triples[{idx}] must be an object/dict")
   131                    continue
   132
   133                # Check required fields
   134                required_block_fields = ["name", "entity_type", "relation", "relevance", "wikipedia_url"]
   135                for field in required_block_fields:
   136                    if field not in block:
   137                        errors.append(f"triples[{idx}] missing '{field}' field\n   Fix: Add \"{field}\" to this triple")
   138
   139                # Validate name is not empty
   140                if "name" in block:
   141                    if not isinstance(block["name"], str) or not block["name"].strip():
   142                        errors.append(f"triples[{idx}] 'name' must be a non-empty string")
   143
   144                # Validate entity_type enum

   140                if "name" in block:

   149                # Validate relation enum

   175
   176                # Check for extra fields (warning only)
   177                allowed_fields = {"name", "entity_type", "relation", "relevance", "wikipedia_url"}
   178                extra_fields = set(block.keys()) - allowed_fields
   179                if extra_fields:

   181
   182    # Check for extra top-level fields (warning only)

   187
   188    # Validate relation requirements based on paper_type

   208                f"   Fix: Identify what new entity the paper introduces/proposes"

   211    return len(errors) == 0, errors

    38def verify_wikipedia_url(url: str) -> tuple[bool, str]:

    45    # Check cache first

    52        msg = "Invalid Wikipedia URL format"
    53        _url_cache[url] = (False, msg)
    54        return False, msg
    55
    56    # Get page title from URL (everything after /wiki/)
    57    page_title = url.replace("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/", "")
    58
    59    # Use Wikipedia REST API to check if page exists
    60    # API endpoint: https://en.wikipedia.org/w/rest.php/v1/page/{title}
    61    api_url = f"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/rest.php/v1/page/{page_title}"
    62
    63    try:
    64        req = urlreq.Request(api_url, headers={'User-Agent': 'Mozilla/5.0 (validate_triple_json validator)'})
    65        with urlreq.urlopen(req, timeout=5) as response:
    66            if response.status == 200:
    67                _url_cache[url] = (True, "")
    68                return True, ""
    69            else:

    73    except HTTPError as e:

    75        _url_cache[url] = (False, msg)
    76        return False, msg
    77    except URLError as e:
    78        msg = f"Network error: {e.reason}"
    79        _url_cache[url] = (False, msg)
    80        return False, msg
    81    except Exception as e:
    82        msg = f"Verification failed: {str(e)}"
    83        _url_cache[url] = (False, msg)
    84        return False, msg

Here are the results for your web search on participatory technology:

## Overview

"Participatory technology" encompasses several related concepts and approaches:

### **Participatory Technology Development**
Participatory technology development (PTD) is an approach to learning and innovation that is used in international development as part of projects and programmes relating to sustainable agriculture.(no content)The approach involves collaboration between researchers and farmers in the analysis of agricultural problems and testing of alternative farming practices.

### **Participatory Design**
Participatory design (originally co-operative design or design participation, now often co-design and also co-creation) is an approach to design that attempts to involve a variety of stakeholders (e.g. employees, partners, customers, citizens, end users) in the design process to help ensure the result meets their needs and is usable.

### **Related Applications**

**Participatory Sensing**: Participatory sensing is the concept of communities (or other groups of people) contributing sensory information to form a body of knowledge. A growth in mobile devices, for example smartphones, tablet computers or activity trackers, which have multiple sensors, has made participatory sensing viable in the large-scale.

**Participatory Media**: Participatory media is communication media where the audience can play an active role in the process of collecting, reporting, analyzing and disseminating content.

**Civic Technology**: Civic technology, or civic tech, is the idea of using technology to enhance the relationship between people and government with software for communications, decision-making, service delivery, and political process.

These approaches share the common goal of involving users and communities in technology development and decision-making processes.

I've completed a web search for "political attitude" and found comprehensive information on the topic. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Political culture is the set of attitudes, beliefs, and sentiments which give order and meaning to a political process and which provide the underlying assumptions and rules that govern behavior in the political system.

## How Political Attitudes Develop

Political socialization is the process by which individuals internalize and develop their political values, ideas, attitudes, and perceptions via the agents of socialization.(no content)The most significant agents include, but are not limited to, families, media, education, and peers, along with religion, the state, and community.

## Dimensions of Political Attitudes

Research has identified various ways to analyze political attitudes:

- Leonard W. Ferguson analyzed political values using ten scales and identified three factors: religionism, humanitarianism and nationalism.

- Inglehart's research described dimensions labeled "secularismtraditionalism," which covered issues of tradition and religion, and "survivalism  self expression," which measured issues like acceptance of diversity and innovation.

## Types of Political Culture

One classification system includes Parochial culture, where citizens are only remotely aware of central government and have neither knowledge nor interest in politics.(no content)Subject culture is where citizens are aware of central government and are heavily subjected to its decisions, with the individual aware of politics, its actors and institutions.

I've completed the web search for "survey methodology research." Here's what I found:

## Overview of Survey Methodology

Survey methodology is a field of applied statistics concentrating on human-research surveys that studies the sampling of individual units from a population and associated techniques of survey data collection, such as questionnaire construction and methods for improving the number and accuracy of responses.

## Key Concepts

**Survey Types:** The three general types of survey designs are cross-sectional, successive independent samples, and longitudinal studies.

**Data Collection Tools:** Questionnaires are the most commonly used tool in survey research.(no content)Surveys may be conducted by phone, mail, via the internet, and also in person in public spaces.

**Questionnaire Development:** A questionnaire is a research instrument that consists of a set of questions for the purpose of gathering information from respondents through survey or statistical study, and is typically a mix of close-ended questions and open-ended questions.

## Recent Developments

Since 2018, survey methodologists have started to examine how big data can complement survey methodology to allow researchers and practitioners to improve the production of survey statistics and its quality.

The research covers practical considerations such as interviewer effects, questionnaire design, sampling techniques, and quality assurance in data collection.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "qualitative research"

Links: [{"title":"Qualitative research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qualitative_research"},{"title":"Qualitative marketing research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qualitative_marketing_research"},{"title":"Qualitative Research (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qualitative_Research_(journal)"},{"title":"Qualitative psychological research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qualitative_psychological_research"},{"title":"Qualitative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qualitative"},{"title":"Postqualitative inquiry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postqualitative_inquiry"},{"title":"Quantitative research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantitative_research"},{"title":"Documentary analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Documentary_analysis"},{"title":"Grounded theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grounded_theory"},{"title":"Online qualitative research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_qualitative_research"}]

## Overview of Qualitative Research

Qualitative research is often used to explore complex phenomena or to gain insight into people's experiences and perspectives on a particular topic.(no content)It inquires deeply into specific experiences, with the intention of describing and exploring meaning through text, narrative, or visual-based data, by developing themes exclusive to that set of participants.

## Key Characteristics

Qualitative research examines aspects of human life, including culture, expression, beliefs, morality, life stress, and imagination.(no content)Qualitative research methodologies are oriented towards developing an understanding of the meaning and experience dimensions of human lives and their social worlds.

## Applications and Disciplines

Qualitative research methods have been used in sociology, anthropology, political science, psychology, communication studies, social work, folklore, educational research, information science and software engineering research.

## Data Collection Methods

Qualitative researchers may gather information through observations, note-taking, interviews, focus groups (group interviews), documents, images and artifacts.(no content)Data sources include interview transcripts, videos of social interactions, notes, verbal reports and artifacts such as books or works of art.

## Common Qualitative Methods

Several specific approaches are commonly used in qualitative research:

- Grounded theory is an inductive type of research, based on ("grounded" in) a very close look at the empirical observations a study yields.
- Thematic analysis involves analyzing patterns of meaning.
- Conversation analysis is primarily used to analyze spoken conversations.
- Narrative inquiry studies the narratives that people use to describe their experience.

Web search results for query: "focus group research methodology"

Links: [{"title":"Focus group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focus_group"},{"title":"Online focus group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_focus_group"},{"title":"Nominal group technique - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nominal_group_technique"},{"title":"Online research methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_research_methods"},{"title":"Focus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focus"},{"title":"Extreme users - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extreme_users"},{"title":"Regulatory focus theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulatory_focus_theory"},{"title":"Focusing (psychotherapy) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focusing_(psychotherapy)"},{"title":"Convenience sampling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convenience_sampling"},{"title":"Cohort study - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cohort_study"}]

Here are the key findings about focus group research methodology:

## Definition and Basic Structure

A focus group is a group interview involving a small number (sometimes up to twelve) of demographically predefined participants.(no content)Their reactions to specific researcher/evaluator-posed questions are studied.

## Core Purpose and Applications

Focus groups are used in market research to better understand people's reactions to products or services or participants' perceptions of shared experiences.(no content)Focus groups constitute a research or evaluation method that researchers organize to collect qualitative data through interactive and directed discussions.(no content)Focus groups are also used by sociologists, psychologists, and researchers in communication studies, education, political science, and public health.

## Key Methodological Features

Group members are often free to talk and interact with each other. Instead of a researcher/evaluator asking group members questions individually, focus groups use group interaction to explore and clarify participants' beliefs, opinions, and views.(no content)While the focus group is taking place, the facilitator either takes notes and/or records the discussion for later note-taking in order to learn from the group. Researchers/evaluators should select members of the focus group carefully in order to obtain useful information.

## Advantages

An advantage of focus groups is their fairly low cost compared to surveys because focus groups allow a researcher to obtain results relatively quickly and increase the sample size by including several people at once.

## Online Focus Groups

Discussions generally last one hour to 90 minutes. The moderator guides the discussion using a combination of predetermined questions and unscripted probes.

Web search results for query: "participatory democracy"

Links: [{"title":"Participatory democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_democracy"},{"title":"Participatory democracy in the European Union - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_democracy_in_the_European_Union"},{"title":"Category:Participatory democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Participatory_democracy"},{"title":"Strong Democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_Democracy"},{"title":"Participatory justice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_justice"},{"title":"Types of democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Types_of_democracy"},{"title":"Grassroots democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grassroots_democracy"},{"title":"Decidim - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decidim"},{"title":"Green Left Party - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Party_of_the_Greens_and_the_Left_Future"},{"title":"Participative decision-making in organizations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participative_decision-making"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about participatory democracy:

## Definition

Participatory democracy is a form of government in which citizens participate individually and directly in political decisions and policies that affect their lives, rather than through elected representatives.(no content)Elements of direct and representative democracy are combined in this model.

## Historical Background

Participatory democracy is not a new concept and has existed in various forms since the Athenian democracy.(no content)Its modern theory was developed by Jean-Jacques Rousseau in the 18th century and later promoted by John Stuart Mill and G. D. H. Cole, who argued that political participation is indispensable for a just society.

## Modern Implementation

In the early 21st century, participatory democracy has been more widely studied and experimented with, leading to various institutional reform ideas such as participatory budgeting. 

Some notable examples include:
- Porto Alegre, Brazil adapted a system of participatory budgeting in 1989.
- The plans to rebuild New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina in 2005 were drafted and approved by thousands of ordinary citizens.
- Participatory democracy was a notable feature of the Occupy movement in 2011, where "Occupy camps" around the world made decisions based on the outcome of working groups where every protester had a say.

## Digital Participation

In the early twenty-first century, social media led to changes in the conduct of participatory democracy, with citizens able to join conversations mainly through the use of hashtags, and local governments starting to use social media to make decisions based on public feedback.

- Porto Alegre, Brazil adapted a system of participatory budgeting in 1989.
- The plans to rebuild New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina in 2005 were drafted and approved by thousands of ordinary citizens.
- Participatory democracy was a notable feature of the Occupy movement in 2011, where "Occupy camps" around the world made decisions based on the outcome of working groups where every protester had a say.

## Digital Participation

In the early twenty-first century, social media led to changes in the conduct of participatory democracy, with citizens able to join conversations mainly through the use of hashtags, and local governments starting to use social media to make decisions based on public feedback.
